review.title: Autonomous Reactive Mission Scheduling and Task-Path Planning Architecture for Autonomous Underwater Vehicle
review.abstract: An Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) should carry out complex tasks in a limited time interval. Since existing AUVs have limited battery capacity and restricted endurance, they should autonomously manage mission time and the resources to perform effective persistent deployment in longer missions. Task assignment requires making decisions subject to resource constraints, while tasks are assigned with costs and/or values that are budgeted in advance. Tasks are distributed in a particular operation zone and mapped by a waypoint covered network. Thus, design an efficient routing-task priority assign framework considering vehicle's availabilities and properties is essential for increasing mission productivity and on-time mission completion. This depends strongly on the order and priority of the tasks that are located between node-like waypoints in an operation network. On the other hand, autonomous operation of AUVs in an unfamiliar dynamic underwater and performing quick response to sudden environmental changes is a complicated process. Water current instabilities can deflect the vehicle to an undesired direction and perturb AUVs safety. The vehicle's robustness to strong environmental variations is extremely crucial for its safe and optimum operations in an uncertain and dynamic environment. To this end, the AUV needs to have a general overview of the environment in top level to perform an autonomous action selection (task selection) and a lower level local motion planner to operate successfully in dealing with continuously changing situations. This research deals with developing a novel reactive control architecture to provide a higher level of decision autonomy for the AUV operation that enables a single vehicle to accomplish multiple tasks in a single mission in the face of periodic disturbances in a turbulent and highly uncertain environment.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 1.1 Research Background
sections.text: Autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) have proven their capabilities in cost-effective underwater exploration up to thousands of meters, far beyond what humans can achieve, and are now the first choice for autonomous navigation and various underwater missions. AUVs are widely used for purposes such as inspection and surveying [1], scientific underwater exploration [2], coastal sampling and monitoring [4], benthic habitat mapping [5] to measure turbulence and obtain associated data [6], offshore facilities and mining [8] and military missions [9]. AUVs are generally able to spend long periods of time underwater emissions at a lower cost than manned vessels [10]. Autonomous operation of AUVs in a vast, unknown and dynamic underwater environment is a complicated process, especially when the AUV is required to respond promptly to environmental changes.

sections.heading: 1.1.1 Mission Planning, Task Assigning and Routing in the Current Research
sections.text: An AUV should perform complex tasks in a limited amount of time, but it has limited battery capacity and endurance, so these limitations necessitate the management of deployment time. Obviously, a single AUV is unable to perform all specified tasks in a single mission with limited time and energy. It must manage its resources effectively in order to perform effective and sustained deployment in longer missions without human interaction, and the tasks may have different characteristics, such as priority value, risk percentage and absolute completion time, that are known to the AUV in advance. Assuming that different tasks are distributed over a specific area of deployment, they can be mapped through a network in which their start and end points are represented as waypoints (an example map is shown in Figure 1.1). In this way, the complication of vehicle guidance in a graphically similar terrain can be addressed directly.

sections.heading: 1.1.2 Path Planning in the Current Research
sections.text: In fact, it is the case that most people who are able to move are able to move, are able to move, are able to move. An offline map will be able to do this. In the second phase, the vehicle is viewed from three different angles. In the third category, information about the underwater world and the likely possibilities is provided by a prior input to the AUV. In the third category, it is replaced by a partially known environment in which the vehicle has a general overview of the environment, but the details and unforeseen events remain as an opaque part of the vehicle observation. In the third category, the vehicle will receive no or only little information about the environment.

sections.heading: 1.2.1 Challenges in the Scope of Vehicle Routing and Task Assigning
sections.text: On the other hand, the quality of the vehicle's use is another important consideration to ensure its safety in an uncertain and dynamic environment. A mission planning strategy is able to organize tasks in a precise way to manage the time available and ensure a productive mission. However, this strategy is not designed to deal with immediate changes in the environment, which is a critical concern in an uncertain and dynamic environment. A mission planning strategy is able to organize tasks in a precise way to manage the time available and ensure a productive mission.

sections.heading: 1.2.3 Research Motivation
sections.text: Existing approaches are mainly able to cover only small parts of this problem, i.e. either task definition together with time management or route planning together with the avoidance of obstacles as a safety consideration. In order to fill the gaps of each strategy, the AUV must have a general overview of the environment at the highest level, in order to carry out an autonomous action selection (task selection) and a local movement planner at the lower level, in order to be able to deal successfully with constantly changing situations. The aim of this research is to fulfil the requirements of the AUV autonomously at both high and low levels, in order to make the AUV systems smarter and more robust in managing their availability and adapting to the dynamic environment (see Section 1.3).

sections.heading: 2.4 Autonomous Vehicles Motion Planning (Definition-2)
sections.text: Movement planning in different frameworks and environments has been extensively studied over the last two decades. The identical aspect of motion planning systems (in Definition-2) is that they are obliged to respond to a dynamic environment that is continuously changing in condition. A correct and realistic modeling of the environment, practical assumptions and the selection of an efficient search strategy are the most important steps of any motion planning approach. The first step towards achieving a satisfactory operation is to find an appropriate and efficient method of route planning. In general, the challenges associated with route planning can be viewed from two perspectives: firstly from the applied methods of motion planning (Section 2.4.3) and secondly from the competence of the techniques for real-time applications (Section 2.4.4). Accordingly, previous studies in this area are taken into account in the following disciplines.

sections.heading: 2.4.1 Path Construction Methods
sections.text: There are popular techniques for linking the defined checkpoints, namely: Straight Line Method [56], which is not flexible enough to ensure a smooth transition in linking piece lines; Dubins categories of paths [57], which connect the connections so that the path becomes smoother in linking checkpoints; this method has attracted great interest in mobile robotic path planning and has been widely used in the last ten years [58-60]. Dubins-based methods are criticized for their high computing costs, which affect the real-time performance of the system, especially in the re-planning of paths [61]. Another popular category of railway construction methods is the spline and the piecemeal polynomic strategy, which uses only some variables of the checkpoints to construct a very flexible path curve.

sections.heading: 2.4.2 Path Planning and Optimization
sections.text: In prospective robotics, route planning, or more generally motion planning, is introduced as a multi-purpose optimisation problem aimed at finding a valid optimal trajectory to guide the robot autonomously to the target of interest in the relevant field of application [65,67]. Optimisation is a process defined on the basis of important criteria and requirements for each specific problem. As a rule, travel time and distance, minimum energy consumption or, in some cases, safety options are used as important criteria for assessing the optimum route [68, 69]. In recent years, many attempts have been made and various techniques have been proposed for the movement planning of autonomous robots. The efficiency of route planning techniques has two perspectives: firstly, the techniques that largely focus on the optimum and resolution of the solutions; and secondly, a group of techniques that mainly focus on producing practicable and probable near-optimal solutions with minimal calculation costs.

sections.heading: 2.4.3 State-of-the-art in Autonomous Motion Planning: The Methodological
sections.text: In this group of algorithms, the cost of the best solution is divided into two main groups: A) Classical and graph (grid) based techniques; and B) Artificial intelligence and evolutionary algorithms based on techniques [70].A) Classical and graph search techniques based on graph search techniques use discrete optimal planning on a graph-like search space [71]. The nature of these algorithms are well suited for vehicle routing problems where the standard form of search space is a weighted direction or bi-directional graph. Various graph search algorithms such as Dijkstra, A * or D * algorithms have been applied to the autonomous vehicle planning problem.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Optimization Criterion for Task-Assign/Routing (TAR)
sections.text: In such terrain covered by multiple waypoints / tasks, the vehicle will be asked to complete the largest possible number of tasks with the highest weight in the total time available designated by T-1. Consequently, the TAR model tends to find the most adapted route to T-1, selecting the best sequence of vertexes in the graph to maximize the total weight of the route, which means that the edges with the best tasks are selected in a manner that leads the vehicle to the target vertex while ensuring the time completion of the journey. The problem includes several objectives that should be met during the optimization process. One approach to solving multi-objective problems is the use of multi-objective optimization algorithms. Another alternative is transferring a multi-objective optimization problem into a limited one. In this regard, the objective function is defined in the form of hybrid cost functions (see 3-5) that are required to maximize or include weighted functions.

sections.heading: 3.3 Meta-Heuristics Optimization Algorithms
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that these two are very complex matters, and that this is a very complex and complex matter.

sections.heading: 3.4 Overview of the Meta-Heuristics Employed
sections.text: The ACO algorithm was inspired by Dorigo et al., [117] and is successfully applied to the TSP problem for the first time. This algorithm has proven to be very successful in solving complex problems and is good for assigning tasks due to its discrete nature. On the other hand, the PSO is one of the most flexible optimization methods for solving a variety of complex problems and has been used in several studies in recent decades. PSO is well adapted to multidimensional space and nonlinear functions due to its stochastic optimization of nature, which does not require evolutionary operators to silence the individuals.

sections.heading: 3.4.1 Application of ACO on TAR Approach
sections.text: In ACO, the ants find their way through the probabilistic decision according to the level of pheromone concentration (accumulated pheromone concentration), so that the pheromone trail attracts ants and leads them to the grain source. Accordingly, more pheromone is released on the crowded paths, which is a self-reinforcing process in the search for the fastest route to the target. Over time, the pheromone evaporates, helping the ants to eliminate bad solutions, allowing the algorithm to prevent the solutions from falling to the local optima. The pheromone concentration at the edges keeps the collected information of the ants within the search process. The probability of targeting a node to travel is calculated by (3-6) and then the entire pheromone trail is updated for all solutions according to (3-7).

sections.heading: 3.4.2 Application of GA on TAR Approach
sections.text: The first and last genes of the chromosomes always correspond to the index of the start and destination nodes. A new generation of chromosomes is transferred to the next generation at minimal cost, and the rest is eradicated.

sections.heading: 3.4.3 Application of BBO on TAR Approach
sections.text: The population of habitat candidates in BBO is initialized with a possible route sequence, and each candidate solution holds a quantitative performance index representing the suitability of the solution called Habitat Suitability Index (HSI). High HSI solutions tend to share their useful information with poor HSI solutions. Habitability is related to some qualitative factors known as Suitability Index Variables (SIVs), which is a random vector of integers. Each candidate solution (hi) holds design variables of SIV, emigration rate (μ), immigration rate (λ), and fitness value of HSI. Generally, a bad solution has a higher immigration rate of λ and a lower immigration rate of μ. The SIV vector of hi is likely to be modified by species according to its immigration rate. In the migration process, one of the solutions (hi) is randomly selected to migrate its SIV to another solution.

sections.heading: 3.4.4 Application of PSO on TAR Approach
sections.text: The PSO begins its search process with a population of imax particles initialized by practicable routes. Particle encoding is a very important factor influencing the effectiveness of the algorithm. During the search process, the population of routes is directed towards the regions of interest in the search area. Each particle includes a position and speed that are randomly initialized in a specific area in the search area. The position of each particle (designated by χi; i; i [1, imax]) is recalibrated during the search process by an updated velocity (designated by successi; j; i [1, imax]; j [1, l], where l is the dimension of the search space. Particle position and velocity are iteratively updated according to (3-11). Particle performance is evaluated according to the defined cost functions (1, Umax]; each particle retains its best position.

sections.heading: 3.5 Discussion on the TAR Simulation Results
sections.text: The second benefit of these algorithms is their ability to handle non-linear cost functions. As already mentioned, achieving a near-optimal solution in faster computing time is more important for the purpose of this research, where the modeled environment corresponds to a spatially varying terrain with high uncertainty. The real performance of the applied algorithms on a TAR basis is not fully known; therefore, the computation time would be one of the important performance indicators for evaluating the applied methods. The TAR module in this research uses prepared information about terrain, waypoints, tasks, network connections and their characterizations.

sections.heading: 4.1 Introduction

sections.heading: 4.2 Modelling Operational Ocean Environment
sections.text: The realistic modeling of the field, including offline maps, dynamic / static current maps, moving and static unsafe obstacles provides a thorough testing environment for evaluating the route planner in situations that closely correspond to the real underwater CHAPTER 4. AUV ONLINE REAL-TIME PATH PLANNING82environment. The marine environment for the local route planner is modeled as a three-dimensional environment - 3D: {3.5 x 3.5 km2 (x-y), 1000 m (z)} embodies unsafe static and mobile obstacles in the presence of variable ocean currents, making the simulation process more difficult and realistic. The designed route planner is able to extract authorized areas of application through the real map to prevent collisions with coastal areas, islands and static / dynamic obstacles. In addition, it is able to compensate or take advantage of adverse currents. The proposed area of application is described in detail below.

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Offline Map
sections.text: The presence of prior information about the terrain, coastal location and static obstacles such as the forbidden zones for provision, the location of start, finish and waypoints in the operating area promotes the AUV's ability to plan robust paths. To model a realistic marine environment, a sample of a real map as shown in Figure 4.2 is used. To cluster the coastal areas and authorized water zones, the K-mean cluster method is usually used for partitioning data sets into groups, initializing the method as cluster centers and then refining the clusters iteratively. It behaves when a saturation phase occurs in which there is no further chance for cluster mapping, aiming to minimize a square error.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Mathematical Model with Uncertainty of Static/Dynamic Obstacles
sections.text: In addition to the offline map, on which the coasts are assumed to be known static obstacles, this study also considers various unsafe objects (BB1) in order to include various possibilities of real-world situations. AUV is equipped with sonar sensors to measure the velocity and coordinates of the objects with a degree of uncertainty represented by a normal distribution and formulated as follows: i. quasi-static Uncertain Objects: The position of the object should be placed between the position of the start and end point of the AUV in the given map. sections.heading: 4.3 Formulation of the Local Path-Planning Problem
sections.text: In the general definition of the AUV planning problem, the current states of the AUV (s) and environments are considered in six different areas to calculate a desirable trajectory from one point to another while meeting specific objectives in terms of existing constraints and vehicle characteristics. An efficient path records the minimum travel time / distance and is safe enough to satisfy collision obstacles. The path planner in this study is able to extract feasible areas of a real map to determine the spaces allowed for use where coastal areas, islands, static / dynamic objects and ocean currents are taken into account. Water currents can have a positive or disruptive effect on vehicles where an undesirable flow itself is a disturbance and it can also push floating objects over the path of the AUV. On the other hand, the desirable flow of AUVs towards their destination can motivate; hence, adaptation to water currents is an important factor that influences the overall trajectory of the AUV and the cost of the aircraft generating the AUV.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Path Optimization Criterion
sections.text: Route planning is a NP-hard optimization problem that aims to guide the vehicle to a specific location where it encounters ocean dynamics and vehicle kinematics (max.).An efficient path takes the minimum travel time / distance and is safe enough to meet collision limitations.Route planning aims to meet the following aspects of performance: To minimize path length / time, route planning in this study aims to find the shortest and safest path between two waypoints that take into account the benefits of a desirable flow while avoiding collisions and counter-current fields.AUV is considered a constant thrust force; therefore, battery usage for one path is a constant function of the time and distance traveled.The performance of the path generated is evaluated based on the total time consumption that is proportional to the distance traveled.The summary of the constant water speed for the vehicle is related to the travel time.

sections.heading: 4.3.2 On-line Path Re-planning based on Previous Solution
sections.text: The variable underwater environment presents several challenges that make the AUV mission problematic and cumbersome. A solution to overcome the difficulties mentioned above is to establish an online route planning approach with dynamic and reactive behaviors. Through this approach, the vehicle exercises situational environmental awareness and refines the path until the vehicle reaches the set target points. Thus, the vehicle is able to access desirable flow rates at any time, so that when the current map is updated to accelerate its movement and save energy consumption. KAPTER 4. AUV ONLINE REAL-TIME PATH PLANNING92 In this research, an online route planning mechanism is used so that when the route mapping is triggered, the new optimal path from the current position to the destination is generated by refining the previous solution. In other words, the solution of the previously optimal path is used as the initial solution for calculating the new path and current condition of the previous position, so that the new path is optimally generated by the new one.

sections.heading: 4.4 Overview of the Applied Evolutionary Algorithms
sections.text: Route planning is an optimization problem that aims to guide the vehicle between two specific points with minimum time due to the battery limitation and at the same time to ensure a safe use to cope with various disturbances in the real world. Before briefly checking the evolutionary algorithms used, it is worth mentioning how they are applied to the optimization problem. As already mentioned, B-spline curves are used to parameterize the path. The path generated by B-spline curves is captured from a series of control points, where n is the number of corresponding control points. Therefore, the appropriate location of these control points plays an essential role in determining the optimal path with the coordinates of ϑ1: (x1, y1, z1),..., ϑn: (xn, yn, zn), where n is the number of corresponding control points.

sections.heading: 4.4.1 Application of FA on ORPP Approach
sections.text: The Fireflies Algorithm (FA) is a kind of meta-heuristic algorithm [129], which is captured by scanning the glow patterns of the fireflies. In the FA process, the fireflies are attracted by their brightness, which fades as the distance of the fireflies increases; the brighter fireflies attract the others in the population. The gravitational pull of the fireflies depends on their distance L and the received brightness of the neighboring fireflies; therefore, the fireflies algorithm approaches according to their attraction parameter β, calculated by (4-23):) 1.0 (,] 21 [) () (001021, 22ttt i t jLt i t iLdqqjqijrandeIrrigation xxLij (4-23) In Equation (4-23), the gravitational pull of the fireflies is applied in the glow space algorithm.

sections.heading: 4.4.2 Application of DE on ORPP Approach
sections.text: The DE algorithm is a population-based optimization algorithm that was introduced as a modified version of the genetic algorithm and uses similar evolutionary operators (crossover, mutation, selection) [131]. DE uses floating-point numbers and real encoding to represent problem parameters that improve solution quality and provide faster optimization. the algorithm uses a non-uniform crossover and differential mutation; CHAPTER 4. sections.heading: 4.4.3 Application of PSO on ORPP Approach
sections.text: The PSO is an optimization method that is well suited to the problem of path planning due to its efficiency in handling complex and multi-objective problems (more details and the general definitions of the PSO process can be found in Chapter 3: Section 3.4.4). In the problem of path planning, the particles are encoded by the coordinates of a potential path generated by B-spline curves. Position and velocity parameters of the particles correspond to the coordinates of the B-spline control points used in path generation. As the PSO iterates, each particle is attracted to its local attraction based on the result of the single and swarm search of the particle. The most attractive advantage of the PSO is that it is easy to implement and requires less calculation to converge to the optimal solution. Algorithm 4.4 provides the mechanism of the PSO-based path planning algorithm.

sections.heading: 4.4.4 Application of BBO on ORPP Approach
sections.text: The BBO is an evolution-based technique that imitates the equilibrium pattern of the inhabitants of biogeographical islands [121]. This algorithm has a strong usability, since habitats are never eliminated from the population, but are improved by migration. Further explanations and the general definitions of the BBO process can be found in Chapter 3: Section 3.4.3. In the proposed BBO-based path planner, each habitat corresponds to the coordinates of the B-spline control point I used in path generation, defining Hi as a parameter to be optimized (Ps: (h1, h2,..., hn-1). Habitats are iteratively improved. Algorithm 4.5 explains the pseudo-code of the BBO in path planning. Algorithm 4.5. Pseudo-code of BBO-based path planning. CHAPTER 4. sections.heading: 4.5 Simulation Results of the Local ORPP Approach
sections.text: There is a clear difference between the theoretical understanding of evolutionary algorithms and their suitability for application to different problems due to the size, complexity and nature of different problems. This can lead to different results by using different algorithms for the same problem. Therefore, a careful selection of evolutionary methods is essential. An efficient path planner is able to use desirable currents and deal with adverse currents to increase battery life. Furthermore, the uncertainty of the field of application, which is more or less taken into account in the literature, has a devastating effect on the safe use of a vehicle. According to the defined path cost function C, the optimal solution corresponds to the fastest and safest path in an uncertain underwater environment. Therefore, the performance of the path planner in coping with current variations and collision avoidance must be thoroughly addressed in accordance with the complexity of the modeled terrain.

sections.heading: Simulation Setup and Research Assumptions
sections.text: The REMUS vehicles selected for this study have the following specifications: It is a modular AUV model with dimensions of 0.2 m in diameter, 1.6 m in length and less than 45 kg in weight. It is equipped with a long range of 75-540 kHz, which operates at 75 kHz and is able to measure currents up to 1 km in front of the vehicle. It is equipped with upward-looking sonar sensors, which operate within a range of 75-540 kHz to detect and measure obstacles.

sections.heading: Scheduling and Path Planning
sections.text: (ARMSP) Architecture

sections.heading: 5.1 Introduction
sections.text: Providing a higher level of decision-making autonomy is a real challenge in the evolution of today's AUVs and promotes a single vehicle to perform multiple tasks in a single mission, as well as the accompanying changes in a turbulent and highly uncertain environment that have not yet been fully achieved. Today's AUVs operation is still limited to very specific tasks with limited autonomy that require managing endurance times. Improving the level of autonomy makes it easier for the vehicle to perform long-distance operations with minimal monitoring in severe unknown environments. The progressive approach builds on the most recent two chapters (chapters 3 and 4) to construct a comprehensive structure for AUV mission planning, routing, task-time management and synchronous online motion planning that adapts to sudden changes in the time environment. This chapter leads to an "Autonomous Reactive Mission Planning and Path Planning" (chapters 3 and 4).

sections.heading: 5.2 Shortcomings Associated with the Mission-Motion Planning
sections.text: The challenges and difficulties associated with motion planning form two perspectives: firstly, the mechanism of the algorithms used; and secondly, the competence of the techniques for real-time applications. In addition to the issues raised with selected strategies in both task assignment / mission planning and motion planning, many technical challenges remain unresolved. Current deviations over time can affect moving obstacles and drive them over the vehicle's path; therefore, the planned trajectory may change and become invalid or inefficient. An adequate assessment of events in such dynamic, uncertain terrain in long-range operations, outside the sensor coverage of the vehicle, is impractical and unreliable. Although available ocean approaches work on a small scale, they produce insufficient accuracy compared to current predictions on a larger scale.

sections.heading: 5.3 Chapter Motivation
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that this project is a project, which is a project that is primarily a project, which is a project that is primarily a project.

sections.heading: 5.4 Mechanism of the Proposed Modular ARMSP Architecture
sections.text: The proposed architecture is designed in separate modules running at the same time. TAR allows the vehicle to select the best sequence of tasks in a limited time so that the vehicle is guided toward its final destination. ORPP deals with vehicle planning from one point to another, taking into account the uncertainty and variability of the oceans. However, the modules interact at the same time by returning situational awareness of the surrounding operating field; accordingly, the system decides to reschedule the path or mission or continue the current mission. Therefore, the "Synchronous" module is designed to manage the lost time within the TAR / ORPP process and reactively adapt the system to the latest updates of the environment and the required decision parameters (e.g. time remaining). The design of the proposed control architecture is illustrated in Figure 5.2.130CHAPTER 5. ARMSP ARCHITECTURE 13of the ultimate TAR Chapter 3 and TPP is explained in ARMSP ARCHITECTURE 1.

sections.heading: 5.5 Discussion and Analysis of Simulation Results
sections.text: The model aims to use the total time available to perform the best possible tasks as efficiently as possible and ensure punctual arrival at the destination, while at the same time ensuring safe deployment through an efficient route planning strategy. CHAPTER 5. ARMSP ARCHITECTURE135To this end, a precise and rigorous match between the various components of the model is required so that each component can assume its responsibilities in sync. Assumptions play an important role in the performance of the model (as described in Section 5.1.1).

sections.heading: 5.5.1 Simulation Setup and Research Assumptions
sections.text: A model of the undersea environment is provided to evaluate the performance of the proposed framework. To model a realistic marine environment, a three-dimensional area at the scale of {10 x 10 km (x-y), 1000 m (z)} is considered on the basis of a realistic sample map represented by Figures 5,4 and 5.5, in which the operating field is covered by uncertain static moving objects, several fixed waypoints and variable ocean currents. For this purpose, a large map of 1000 x 1000 pixels is carried out, covering 10 x 10 km square area for the TAR and a smaller part of the map in the size of 350 x 350 pixels, corresponding to the coast, the water and unsafe area of the map, in order to implement and test the ORPP performance. In this map, each pixel corresponds to 10 x square space. The clustered map is converted into a matrix format, in which the Drix-density matrix is the density of the map.

sections.heading: 5.5.2 ARMSP Performance on Scheduling and Time Management for Reliable
sections.text: The proposed architecture provides another reason for the rapid operation of the proposed approach. Thus, two of the proven algorithms are able to apply a variety of algorithms and perfectly synchronize them to achieve a unique performance. Thus, the performance of the model is independent of the way in which different algorithms are applied by their different components. The reason for this advantage is that two different perspectives on the autonomy of the vehicle are combined in high-level tasks. In order to cover the deficiencies of the railway planning when it is operated on a large scale, the operational field for the operation of the ORPP is divided into smaller spaces (by higher layer TAR); therefore, the re-planning of a new railway requires the reproduction and recalculation of less information. This leads to a reduction of the problem space and a reduction in the computer-related load, which is another reason for the rapid operation of the proposed approach.

sections.heading: 5.6 Chapter Summary
sections.text: This chapter develops an autonomous reactive architecture of the ARMSP, which includes both high-level decision-makers and low-threshold action generators, based on two mission plans (TAR) and directions (ORPP), which have been implemented and evaluated in two previous chapters. ARMSP can simultaneously organize the tasks based on its priority, risk and completion time. At the lower level, it is also able to improve the maneuverability of the vehicle and increase its autonomy for operation in a confusing and uncertain environment. The proposed architecture provides a certain degree of flexibility for the use of a number of algorithms and can effectively lead to stable performance.

sections.heading: Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: This chapter summarizes the context of the research carried out and shows the most important results of this thesis. Therefore, recommendations for possible future work are proposed.

sections.heading: 6.2.2. AUV Online Real-Time Path Planning (ORPP): (Chapter 4)
sections.text: It is necessary to respond to changes in an unfamiliar and dynamic underwater environment, where priority information is not normally available, and the route planning scenario is defined by a highly complex and variable operating field. Providing a certain level of autonomy enables the vehicle, and in particular the route planner, to take advantage of the favourable flow of electricity for energy management. In order to achieve an exact adaptation to the variations of the underlying environment, a novel online route planning module from ORPP has been developed and implemented, which is capable of refining the original route taking into account current flows, uncertain static and mobile obstacles. This refinement is not calculatably expensive, as there is no need to calculate the route from the ground up and to use the obtained solutions of the original route, resulting in a reduction in the optimisation space that speeds up the search process.

sections.heading: 6.3 Future Research Directions
sections.text: Building on the contributions of this research, future work will focus on designing additional modules that cover vehicle self-confidence and fault tolerance, as well as developing vehicles "ability to assess risk and manage risks as their failure due to costly maintenance is unacceptable, and integrating the architecture with an additional predictor corrector module that includes the ability to predict situational perception of the environment at least one step ahead, giving greater flexibility for a successful mission in real-world experiments.

sections.heading: Direction ①: Internal Situation Awareness (SA) and Fault Tolerance
sections.text: The vehicle is able to detect an internal failure and to diagnose the fault tolerance accordingly.

sections.heading: Direction ②: Data Fusion and External (Environmental) Situation Awareness
sections.text: In both cases, it will be necessary for the information to be diagnosed, classified and efficiently retrieved by the SA and the decision-making unit when carrying out a mission. The relationship between the information received will be used for the extraction and classification of events, such as the detection of threatening obstacles, the management of unexpected and uncertain disturbances, etc. In order to raise awareness of the surrounding environment, not only the individual obstacles should be identified, but also higher order relationships between the different objects in order to detect the threat and uncertainty of an obstacle.

sections.heading: Direction ③ Mission Risk Probability Assessment
sections.text: The failure of the AUV in the ocean is unacceptable due to the expensive maintenance, and from another point of view, the system must have a general background of near future conditions in order to have a quick and punctual interaction with the environment, and should be able to make an orderly decision in the event of fully non-deterministic events known as autonomous decision-making, which will improve the system's ability to react quickly to the various unknown events and improve the overall autonomy of the vehicle operating in dangerous, uncertain environments, a reliable and appropriate risk assessment strategy will help the vehicle to understand its hazardous environment, interact with the new inexperienced events, and effectively deal with the unforeseen and unknown phenomena, and the information derived from SA will be used to provide the decision maker with the ability to understand how the model arrives at a decision. Risk probability assessment is another direction that can be expanded and taken into account.

sections.heading: Direction ④: Multiple Vehicle Cooperative Operation Using ARMSP Model
sections.text: The proposed control architecture has the potential to upgrade and deploy multiple vehicles for multiple missions without conflict. In this case, if a vehicle is removed from the team (and for some reason aborts its mission), the closest vehicles with the most similar configurations will take over the incomplete mission, or the mission will be split across multiple vehicles and the system plans a new mission scenario for all vehicles. Advantages of using multiple vehicles in collaborative operations include covering long missions in larger areas, increased fault tolerance, improved system stability and robustness, and better risk management. By using Underwater Wireless Sensor Networks (UWNS), vehicles can communicate and exchange useful local information.

sections.heading: Further Benefits and Applications:
sections.text: The model I developed focused on AUVs, but was specifically designed to be generalized and compatible with other classes of autonomous applications, in particular autonomous unmanned aerial, ground, or surface vehicles. Such a modular structure specifically increases the reusability and versatility of the system, where upgrading or updating the functionality of a module does not require changing the entire architecture structure. On the other hand, running the modules in parallel speeds up the calculation process and also increases the accuracy of the system in autonomous operation while managing all internal and external situations. 171

sections.heading: Missions
sections.text: Abstract - This paper presents a solution to the common problem of route planning and task assignment for autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) on a large scale. Given a number of constraints (e.g. time) and a number of task priorities, the goal is to find the optimal route for underwater missions that maximizes the sum of priorities and minimizes the overall risk while adhering to the prescribed constraints. Based on the heuristic nature of genetic and swarm intelligence algorithms for solving NP-hard graph problems, Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Genetic Algorithm (GA) are used to find the optimal solution, with each individual in the population being a candidate solution (route). To evaluate the robustness of the proposed methods, the performance of all PS and GA algorithms is examined and compared for a number of Monte Carlo runs. Simulation results suggest that the algorithms are reliable enough for both the planning and the use of the water.

sections.heading: Planning Method for AUV Guidance in
sections.text: a Dynamic Cluttered EnvironmentAbstract - Promoting the level of autonomy makes it easier for the vehicle to perform long-range operations with minimal monitoring; the ability of autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) to fulfil mission objectives is directly influenced by route planning and task assignment system performance; this paper proposes an efficient route planning model for task assignment in a semi-dynamic operational network, where the position of some waypoints changes over time in a limited area. To investigate the performance of the method in the context of mission productivity, mission time management and vehicle safety, a series of biogeography-based optimizations (BBO) and particle swarm optimizations (PSO) are performed to provide real-time optimal solutions for task sequence selection and mission time management. To examine the performance of the method in the context of mission productivity, mission time management and vehicle safety, a series of Monte Carlo simulation trials are conducted.

sections.heading: Uncertain Underwater Environment
sections.text: Abstract - The three-dimensional route planning of AUV in complex turbulent underwater environments is investigated in this study, which takes into account static flow data and uncertain static moving time variant obstacles. Robustness of AUV route planning to this strong variability is known as a complex NP-hard problem and is considered a critical problem to ensure the safe use of vehicles. Efficient evolutionary techniques have considerable potential for dealing with NP-hard complexity of the route planning problem as more powerful and faster algorithms among other approaches to this problem. To this end, the Differential Evolution (DE) technique is used to solve the AUV route planning problem in a realistic underwater environment. The route planners designed in this work are able to extract feasible areas of a real map to determine the allowable application areas where coastal areas, islands, static obstacles / dynamic currents and low ocean currents are considered.

sections.heading: Algorithms
sections.text: Abstract - In this study, a single autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) is converted into a nonlinear Optimal Control Problem (NOCP) and numerical solutions are then provided. A streamlining method is used to combine boundary conditions, vehicle-specific and environmental constraints with the performance index, which is the final rendezvous time. Four evolutionary-based path planning methods, namely Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Biogeographical-based Optimization (BBO), Differential Evolution (DE) and the Firefly Algorithm (FA) are used to establish a reactive planner module and provide a numerical solution for the proposed NOCP. The goal is to synthesize and optimize the performance and performance of the aforementioned methods in order to steer an AUV from an initial locator point to a rendezvous planer.

sections.heading: Underwater Mission
sections.text: Abstract - An autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) must have a certain degree of autonomy for a given underwater mission in order to successfully achieve the mission objectives and ensure its safety at all stages of the mission in a large-scale field of operations. In this paper, a novel combinatorial conflict-free task assignment strategy is introduced, consisting of an interactive engagement of a local route planner and an adaptive global route planner. The proposed hybrid method uses the heuristic searchpower of the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm to address the discrete nature of the routing task assignment approach and the complexity of the NP hardpath planning problem. The proposed hybrid method is highly efficient as a result of its reactive leadership framework, which ensures the successful completion of missions, especially in cluttered environments. In order to examine the performance of the method in the context of mission productivity, mission time management and vehicle safety, a series of simulation studies will be conducted.

sections.heading: Planning and Task-Time Management
sections.text: Abstract - Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) are able to spend long periods of time carrying out various underwater missions and naval tasks. In this paper, a novel, conflict-free motion planning framework is introduced to improve the mission performance of underwater vehicles by maximizing the number of tasks of highest priority in a limited period of time through a large-scale operation field crowded with waypoints and ensuring safe deployment during the mission. The proposed combinatorial route planner model takes advantage of the biogeography-based optimization algorithm (BBO) to meet the objectives of both higher and lower motion planners, guaranteeing maximization of mission productivity for a single vehicle operation. The performance of the model is examined under various scenarios, including particular cost constraints in time-varying operational fields. To demonstrate the reliability of the proposed model, the performance of each individual motion planner is evaluated individually and then statistically analyzed to evaluate the overall performance of the model.

sections.heading: Motion Planning and Task Assignment
sections.text: Abstract - Extending today's underwater scenarios and missions requires the consideration of robust autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) decision-making; therefore, designing an efficient decision framework to maximize mission productivity in a limited time.This paper focuses on the development of a conflict-free advisory assignment architecture, comprising a Global Route Planner (GRP) and a Local Path Planner (LPP), to provide consistent motion planning that takes into account both environmental dynamics changes and a priori knowledge of the terrain, so that AUV is reactive in the context of an uncertain underwater environment.The architecture includes three main modules: The top-level GRP module deals with task priority assignment, mission time management, and determining a viable route between take-off and destination in a large-scale environment.The LPP module at the bottom level deals with free collision between vehicles and safety considerations.

sections.heading: Environment
sections.text: Abstract - This paper presents a hybrid route planning model for the assignment and management of the tasks of an autonomous underwater vehicle during the operation of the AUV by the variable coastal waters. First, several priority tasks are defined, distributed over a large area; then, an appropriate deployment time and energy management is carried out, taking into account the limitations of the deployment time, the vehicle battery, the uncertainty and variability of the underlying field of application; the proposed goal is achieved by the inclusion of a route planner responsible for the priority list of available tasks according to the available battery, and a route planner that acts on a smaller scale to ensure the safe deployment of the vehicle against sudden environmental changes. The synchronous process of task assignment and route planning is simulated using a specific composition of differential evolution and firefly optimization (DEFO). The simulation results indicate that the minimum performance of the proposed hybrid model 404 during the positive energy 4C will result in a weighted hybrid 404.

sections.heading: A Hierarchal Planning Framework for
sections.text: AUV Mission Management in a Spatio-Temporal Varying OceanAbstract - The purpose of this work is to provide a hierarchical dynamic mission planning framework for a single autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) to perform a task assignment process in a limited time interval while operating in an unsafe underwater environment, taking into account the spatial and temporal variability of the mission field. To this end, a high-level reactive mission planner and low-motion planning system will be constructed. The high-level system will be responsible for the task priority and will guide the vehicle toward a goal, taking into account a timely completion of the mission. The lower layer will be responsible for generating optimal trajectories based on the task sequence and dynamics of the mission site. The mission planner will be able to reactively rearrange the tasks based on mission / terrain updates, while correcting low-level trajectories by managing the terrain planner's unexpected changes in the position of the new trajectory.

sections.heading: Realistic Sever Ocean Environment
sections.text: Abstract - The operation of AUVs today is limited to very specific tasks with little real autonomy due to battery constraints. Efficient route planning and deployment planning are prerequisites for progressive autonomy and facilitate the vehicle's handling of long-distance operations. A single vehicle cannot perform all tasks over large terrain; therefore, a degree of autonomy is required in the execution of robust decisions and awareness of the mission / environment to resolve trade-offs between tasks to be performed, manage available time, and ensure safe deployment at all stages of the mission. In this regard, this research introduces a modular control architecture that includes higher / lower level planners, with the higher level module responsible for increasing mission productivity by assigning priority tasks while guiding the vehicle to its final destination in an area surrounded by multiple waypoints; and the lower level is responsible for the safe deployment of the vehicle, including higher / lower scale obstacles, taking into account the varying operating time and lower actual movement.

sections.heading: Reactive Mission and Path Planning
sections.text: (RRMPP) ArchitectureAbstract - Providing a higher level of decision-making autonomy is a real challenge in the development of today's AUVs and promotes a single vehicle to perform multiple tasks in a single mission, as well as the associated immediate changes in a turbulent and highly uncertain environment. The approach builds on recent research to create a comprehensive structure for AUV mission planning, routing, task time management and synchronous online motion planning that adapts to sudden changes in the time variant environment. Respectively, this paper constructs an "Autonomous Reactive Mission Planning and Path Planning" (ARMSP) architecture, and a set of evolutionary algorithms are used by different layers of the proposed control architecture to examine the efficiency of the structure in terms of addressed goals and demonstrate the stability of its performance in real-time mission planning and threat management.
